stimulusHtml:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.


The common house finch is a small songbird that begins to look for a mate in early winter. An ecologist plans to investigate the number of mating calls per hour for the finch during mating season. A previous report suggests the population distribution of the number of mating calls per hour for the finch is skewed to the right with mean μ=330 and standard deviation σ=144.

(a) Compare the shapes of the sampling distributions of the sample mean number of mating calls per hour for random samples of 5 finches and for random samples of 50 finches from the population. Explain your answer.

(b) Which of the following would be less likely to obtain from the population?

• A random sample of 36 finches having a mean number of mating calls per hour that is greater than 336

or

• A random sample of 256 finches having a mean number of mating calls per hour that is greater than 336

Justify your answer.

The ecologist conducted a study to investigate whether the number of mating calls per hour for finches is different for two exhibit temperatures. The ecologist randomly assigned 70 common house finches from a local zoo to be placed in one of two exhibits, with 35 placed in an exhibit with a certain outdoor temperature and 35 placed in an exhibit with a temperature warmer than the outdoor temperature. Several zoo employees, who did not have knowledge of each finch’s assigned exhibit temperature, listened to one-hour recordings of each finch’s songs and counted the number of mating calls the finch made.

The boxplots show the results of the study.

(c) Based on the boxplots, write a few sentences comparing the distributions of the number of mating calls per hour for the finches placed in an exhibit with the outdoor temperature and the finches placed in an exhibit with the warmer temperature.

The ecologist will conduct a hypothesis test to investigate whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that the mean number of mating calls per hour is different for finches in the outdoor temperature than in the warmer temperature.

(d) Name the appropriate hypothesis test and state, in words, the hypotheses.

Assume the conditions for inference have been met. A 99 percent confidence interval for the difference in the mean numbers of mating calls per hour (warmer temperature minus outdoor temperature) was calculated to be −29.303±78.197.

(e) Based only on this confidence interval, is the difference in the mean numbers of mating calls per hour statistically significant? Justify your answer.
(f) Can the findings of this study be generalized to all common house finches? Explain why or why not.
